text: Appearance is a clear pale yellow. Aroma is a bit of solvent at first and then becomes very fresh and is short-lived. Flavor is sweet upfront a bit savory and pleasant goes very well with cheese. Body is a touch thin and finish is somewhat long and like apples or pears.

Bottle 180ml. [ As Kikusakari Gekkakow Vintage Daiginjo Sake ].ABV: 17.0%. Clear light light light yellow color with virtually no head. Aroma is moderate to light heavy rice, alcohol. Flavour is moderate sweet with a long duration, alcohol, rice, honey sweetness, late finish is dry. Body is medium, texture is watery, carbonation is flat, finish feel is light alcoholic. [20140316]
Bottle at Craigs. Pours clear pale golden. Im not really a big fan of sake. Light pineapple maybe? Rice wine.
Bottle at Craigs. Pours clear pale golden, slight earthy pineapple nose, dry, fruity.
bottle at home ... lightest yellow .... soft sweet earthy rice ... soft fruits nose... light umami mushroom that builds... I REALLY DONT LIKE aged sakes

Bottle, tasted and reviewed 08/19/2013. Pours light silvery gold color, like pale white whine. Aroma is pear, honeyed crisp apple, tart raspberry sweetness, cantaloupe, light toasted rice, touch of wood. Taste is pear, cantaloupe, juicy watermelon, round and full, mild rice finish. Body is silky, incredibly smooth, no heat, well balanced by avoiding excessive sweetness. Great.

Very soft nose - what you get is inviting though. Unique flavour for a sake. RIce, apple and an almost wine like dryness and light umeshu like taste. Good body. Very appealing, though not worth 3000+ yen a bottle.

Blueberry and pear nose. Clear, very pale yellow with a greenish tint. Balanced plum flavor, subtle, some heat. Finishes with melon rind. I actually prefer the Kurahibiki Daiginjo-shu from Kikusakari, but this was pretty good too.

Bottle (I think an 06) thanks to cquiroga. Pours with a clear body with a gold tinge. Aroma is a bit musty, nearly like a light koshu, with hints of cobwebs, attic and tobacco. Also some notes of honey. Taste is honey, caramel, tobacco, herbal and light koji. A very interesting sake. Syrupy and well balanced mouthfeel with absolutely hidden alcohol.

Not 100% this goes here but I will find out tonight and move it if I have to.  Pours , still, and clear with a light yellow color.  Legs on the glass with each swirl.  Aroma of pears with mild rice and alcohol notes. A spicy licorice and flowers with warming of the sake.  The flavor  has a vanilla start with a light fruity (lychee) middle.  Semi-dry finish leaves a long taste.  Warming but light and no real alcohol taste.
Pours clear and still.  Smells of vanilla, touches of fruit, some rice, alcohol.  Tastes of vanilla, sweet rice, alcohol, some fruity hints on the finish.

Pours still, with a crystal clear, pale yellow body.  A swirl of the glass reveals sticky, runny legs.  Notes of cream, lemon chiffon, koji, licorice and sweet bread comprise the inviting nose.  A substantial, oily, sweet body pushes along those same creamy and citrus notes in the mouth.  Un-parallelled smoothness feels excellent from start to finish.  Ends semi-dry.  Hides the 17.5% incredibly well.  Perfect with sushi.  Complex enough for deep contemplation, yet simple enough for everyday drinking.  Great Daiginjo.

Vintage 2000. Clear lightly yellowed liquid. Thick tall legs. LIghtly floral aroma, with hints of mums and honeysuckle. Not a strong aroma, but one that keeps calling you back. Very fruity in flavor, with pears, apricots, and a few exotic fruits as well. Strength is not that well hidden in this one as the alcohol come in mid to late finish and starts a small fire that builds in the linger. A touch of dry coconut in the linger. The alcohol is not tasted, but rather felt which is a plus. You can tell this is the good stuff, but I wish the flavors did come out a touch more.

This dark green 2003 vintage bottled sake from a bottle shop poured a very small sized head of frothy clear colored bubbles that were quickly diminishing and left behind a transparent and an oily lacing. The aroma was vinous alcohol secondary rice and licorice. The semi-thick mouth feel was weakly tingly at the start mediumly tingly at the finish with a biting vinous alcohol aftertaste. . An OK sake just nothing special.

Vintage 2000.  Thanks to Blake.
Clear pour yellowish haze thick leggs ride the glass and hold.  Pleasant fruity aroma definate rice liquor as well, very sweet, hints of pears and cocconut.  Nice delicate palate, coats well and lingers.  Flavor is warm alcohols some light green mellon, cocconun, pear, and a sweet finish  Very nice sake!

Vintage 2000.  The sake pours to a light yellow hued glassy clear body with really sexy legs and a nice reflective property exists with the light play.  The aroma is coconut, melon, rice, Asian pears, and some sort of herbs.  The flavor is coconut, rice, melon, vanilla, and plum flowers.  The palate is creamy, warming, and nicely textured.

Bottled, Vintage 2000, very special thanks to Blake!  Poured a clear almost watery color, but had a tint of yellow to it... very nice legs to it.  Aroma picked up some alcohol-fueled melons, some berries, and more fusel alcohol, especially as it warmed up.  Flavor had a very intriguing berry and melon character that washed over the front of the palate.. some floral and some well-refined rice over the middle with a warm melon and polished rice back-end.  Warm on the palate throughout with solid fruity notes and melon throughout.  Tasty stuff that flowed very well across the palate.. warm, inviting, and eminently enjoyable!  Thanks Blake!
Fruity aroma, strawberries mixed with kumquats.  Pours clear.  Smooth, alcohol, some fruits like berries and citrus, over powered by alcohol.

Nice off clear color,aroma of fruits and maybe a hint of alcohol in the back ground but mostly fruity all around.The flavor comes off as being much the same as the aroma,some citrus and maybe some dryed fruits alnog with a mild alcohol presence.Very very nice brew that i could easily sit and drink until its gone.

Tryed 1992 reserve Kikusakari Daiginjo. Fantastic fruit aroma, with a strong pear core smell. Very light in the sake cup, with only a slight yellowing. Wow...the smell. Taste rolls over your tongue in a more subtle way than most daiginjo sakes. Unbelievable fruity taste...I taste pear, pineapple, orange, cherry, plum...it goes on. Tutti frutti is the best word for it. Dont miss this. It will turn you into a sake fanatic.

Tried at the new NYC restaurant, Megu, in Tribeca (Manhattan).  Their "kimono bar" has walls lined with rolls of kimono cloth and the sake menu was assembled with the help of John Gauntner - the #1 English-speaking sake expert.  Boasting about 20 daiginjos, the list was impressive, and I settled on the Gekkakow, which was immensely fragrant of candy and sweetness.  Again, it reminds me of cotton candy from the circus, and is quite sweet for sake.  The abv is NOWHERE to be found, as you'd expect from such a premium offering.  Light body with hints of fruit.  Delicious.
